When we first visited Cincy, we checked out Findlay Market (a wonder in itself), and discovered Dojo. Since it was early May, they had made "Mint Julep" in honor of Derby, and the bourbon & mint taste was so realistic, so amazing, that I felt like a lush for eating it before lunch. We also had the "Peanut Butter Stracciatella", which was rich and like a really high-class Reese's Cup.

I've said it before--I adore ice cream. You've no idea how much thought I give to ice cream. It's a sickness, I know. So I'm telling you, I KNOW ice cream, and Dojo is fantastic. They use real ingredients (not flavorings--there was real bourbon in that Mint Julep).

They handcraft the stuff, so its made in small batches and when it's gone for the day, it's gone until they decide to make that flavor again. And I won't lie, it's pricey (I don't eat as much as I'd like because of that fact), but if you have the $$, it's absolutely worth it. Treat yourself at their Findlay Market location or when you see the Dojo Cart around town!

Have I really not reviewed Dojo? How could I not have already discussed how I cannot visit Findlay Market without being suckered into buying a little cup of Dojo Gelato. Evil, evil, I say. I love gelato, and I love Dojo Gelato. 

You won't get your typical gelato here, but who wants that anyway? You will find many fun and funky flavors in creamy delicious form.  They sound weird, but taste really good. The tiny small size is plenty for me though, it's that rich. I always get half and half to try two flavors, and haven't been disappointed yet.

This gelato stand is a cool idea, but unfortunately, the gelato isn't really that great.  It has a good, smooth texture and is prepared the traditional way.  However, the other selling point to gelato is the rich flavors.  Dojo Gelato kind of misses the mark on that one.  The sea salt caramel tastes mostly like salt (so, I guess that's rich, technically), and the chocolate doesn't really taste very chocolatey.  It's really unfortunate because I yearn to love everything in Findlay Market.  The gelato here is definitely not bad, it's just not really exciting at all.  When I have such excellent dessert options as Yagoot, Aglamesis Brothers, and Graeter's in the city, well, I'm just likely to go somewhere else.

Bottom Line:  I'd be back if I needed dessert at Findlay Market.

just experienced Dojo Gelato for the first time today down at findlay market.

I think one of the best things about dojo is their variety of vastly different flavors. I sampled a salted carmel and olive oil. I ended up with Mexican vanilla and a spicy chocolate, the name of it escapes me. the Spicy chocolate had a mean bite to it but the vanilla really cooled it down. they let me sample a bunch of different flavors. The olive oil was strange  but i could see how it would be great with other flavors. A regular cup is about 4 bucks and is more than enough serving for something so rich. The staff was friendly. Ill defiantly visit again when I am in findlay market.

In the interest of full disclosure, I know the owner. However, even if I didn't know him from Adam, I'd still be obsessed with it.

You know you've found a good stand at Findlay if you can't get near it. Dojo is right by an entrance and most often you will find the area clogged. But be patient, it's worth it!

My favorite is actually a sorbetto, the lemon rosemary. Every flavor I've tried has been fantastic. Love the olive oil, lavender honey, pistachio and egg nog. Don't be afraid of the "weird" flavors that don't seem to belong in gelato--if you give them a try I promise you'll see that Michael's interpretation works!

A very welcome addition to Findlay Market, the kids at Dojo Gelato are dishing out delicious and creative takes on Italian ice cream. 

Try the Porkopolis (flavored with BACON!).

My new favorite (sorry Madisono's) gelato. *Maybe* my new favorite ice cream.

Walked past this stand on Saturday and my eyes lit up at the sight of pistachio gelato! I waited in line and went to order a medium cup of the pistachio. Oops... it wasn't pistachio... it was avocado. It had the same coloring that is typically seen with pistachio. Even as an avocado lover, I can't imagine that avocado is a very popular flavor for gelato. The girl behind the counter recommended that I try the Nocciolo instead - describing it as an Italian hazelnut flavor. I wasn't particularly impressed with this flavor and at $5.25 for a 4 ounce serving, I don't see myself trying any of the others any time soon. Now, if I see pistachio on my next visit, I might change my mind.

I don't know why it took me so long to write a review for Dojo Gelato! It's beyond ice cream... beyond simple confections you can find anywhere else... it's creamy, delicious creativity!

Located at a far end of Findlay Market, there are a number of flavors of gelato from which you can choose: from the simplicity of vanilla or chocolate, to the slightly more insane Captin' Crunch or Hot Chocolate (it's spicy, yum!), and everywhere in between.

My personal favorite is to get a small (hey, I have to portion-control somehow!) with half Nutella gelato and half Vanilla Bean gelato. Another honorable mention is Vanilla Bean and Veitnamese Coffee.

Just thinking about this place makes me want to grab my keys and go to Findlay Market for a gelato fix... maybe I will...!

We visited Findlay today and I tried Dojo for the second time. The first time, I wasn't so impressed. It was good but didn't rock my world. But today? Today I am a changed woman after sampling the Vietnamese coffee and Fior de Latte. 
The Vietnamese coffee was beyond fantastic! The coffee flavor wasn't kick-you-in-the-pants intense but it was definitely there. My three-year old niece absolutely loved it. She waltzed through Findlay in a post-Vietnamese coffee euphoria.  
The Fior de Latte was some tasty business for sure. It's subtly sweet and so creamy. It made me want to hug a cow. 
And the people there are friendly and it's inexpensive. Definitely worth a stop if you're in the area.

Loved LOVED LOVE IT. Read about this place on yelp and it did not disappoint! I got the 2 flavor cup with Dutch chocolate and salted caramel. It was so yummy and much better for you than ice cream! My boyfriend and I can't wait to return and try some new flavors, and def trying an espresso! Any suggestion espresso lovers ?

Believe me, I want to like it.  I DO!  Maybe I just don't have a taste for Gelato or something.  I have tried many of their flavors and the only one I would ever be interested in putting in my mouth ever again is the chocolate. 

I'll probably keep trying and in turn, keep wondering why.

This is not a review for the gelato, but for the espresso. I don't know if it was an off day, or what, but I ordered a double espresso and (it took a while to make) when I tried it, it tasted so burnt and sour that after some debate, I returned and asked for a new one. A guy who looked in charge apologized and pulled the next serving himself (and I get that making espresso is kind of time consuming, but at this point I had waited about 10 cumulative minutes for 2 little cups of espresso in a very packed area and was a bit frustrated/embarrassed). Unfortunately, he did not use a spoon or straw to taste it himself, handed it to me, and (again) it had that bitter/sour/burnt flavor, and was unpalatable. At that point I was not going to complain and wait again in such a busy/packed space, so I walked out and just threw it away. I'm sure there was a less passive-aggressive way to resolve this, but at that point I was done, and their vibe did not seem to overly seek out feedback (eg: "Hey, so sorry it didn't work, please let us know if it's ok, it's no problem if it's not...") so the easiest solution was just to walk away.
One of the better frozen treats I've had in the midwest. A little pricey, but a good reward for a hard week of work.

I love gelato, so it would be hard for me to have anything negative to say about Dojo.  On a beautiful warm sunny day, one can sit outside of Findlay Market with a cup (or cone, the cones are unique and delicious, the sweetness doesn't hit you til the end) of gelato and think, "man, life can't get much better than this."  I had the Chocolate n' Porter and it was great, it tasted like a dark chocolate; it was also very rich as I couldn't finish one tiny scoop (a rarity for me).  I just wish they had more flavors at any given time, but I suppose this will only entice me to keep returning frequently, to see what new and interesting flavors they have come up with.

Ice cream of the Italian persuasion...

...in my one stop grocery store ;)- Dojo sits at the entrance of the main pavilion at Findlay market in downtown Cincy. If you aren't familiar with Italian style ice cream, this is the place to get your fix. Don't be alarmed by all it's crazy flavors- Guiness, green tea or even plain chocolate, they are all fantastic. But remember, a little goes a long way- don't need much to appease your sweet tooth. And while your there, don't forget to snag a waffle from Belgium waffles right up the aisle to go with your new favorite cold tastey treat!

I LOVE THIS PLACE.

My mom and I stopped here to get some gelato for my sister's birthday.  We picked up a pint of The Elvis and Kit Kat. My sister LOVES Kit Kats so it was perfect that they had it for her birthday. We all loved the Elvis too. It had a great banana flavor. 

While we picked up the pints we had to (of course) gte some to go. I had half pistachio and half blackberry. My mom had half vanilla and half lemon. 

I am going to say hands down out of all the gelato I've had from Dojo the Pistachio was the best. I love it. I dream about it at night.  

The rest were great too- I tried the lemon and loved it too- I am a big fan of lemon flavored things and it was very lemony and delicious.

Also everyone was very friendly. Overall it was an excellent experience. Can't wait to try some more flavors!

I don't make it out to Findlay Market very much, but when I do, Dojo is a staple for my visits.

And that, coming from the least adventurous, non-dessert loving person you can imagine. 

But what won me over was Dojo's rotation of flavors, never keeping the same things on the shelves to get boring. Instead, a mix of new and old get thrown together to make a weekly challenge out of what to order. (My personal favorite being the bourbon) 

I imagine if you're new to Cincinnati, Dojo shouldn't be anything to go out of your way for. It's delicious, but with so many things to take in all over the city, save this for your second trip. 

But maybe in a few years, that'll change. 

With the addition of a van and cart, Dojo may grow to be a local must-have. So I would see it wise to keep an eye on this business.

Dojo is terrific, and wonderfully simple. The menu -cut and dry- the service, the location, all of it's pretty great, and all of it will leave you eagerly awaiting the next list of flavors. Just writing about it is making me wish I had a pint in my freezer.

Great gelato in terms of flavor and texture. interesting selection of flavors as well, reminiscent of jeni's in columbus. some are ok, but there are definitely some outstanding ones like "vietnamese coffee" which is AMAZING.

that plus no artificial anything and hormone free? Sold!

have to thank my foodie buddy for this one as he discovered it!

Creamy, fatty, delicious.  Adventurous flavors to go along with some standard treats.  Be sure to ask for a flavor pairing from the staff if you don't have a favorite.  They will treat you right, and as always, ask for a sample,  no need to waste money on a flavor you aren't going to love.  Expect to pay about 5 bucks per person, servings are a little smaller, but  its for your own good.  You don't want to become Fatty McButter pants overnight do you?

I'm not a huge ice cream or gelato person unless I have a sudden craving for it.  Dojo is a place where I definitely like to go when I want something sweet.  They are always helpful and willing to let you try the flavors before you buy.  Not only do they have your typical flavors but they like to mix it up by carrying some unusual and some gourmet options.  One of my favorites was a very spicy chocolate gelato, which was surprisingly spicy but in a really satisfying way.  They also serve really good coffee and sell it by the pound as well.  If you are at findlay market or if you want gelato you should definitely give Dojo a shot.
Not a fan of gelato. But the flavor is really good! Kind of forget which ones I chose, but you can taste everyone before determine which flavors to go!

Awesome. Friendly staff always willing to let you try their crazy but awesome flavors (Captain crunch and pumpkin ale are two of my husband's favorites) and then some more typical but amazing ones- Vietnamese coffee, Dutch chocolate, spectacular lemon sorbet, and the groovy new lemongrass and lime. 
A trip to Findlay market isn't complete without a trip to Dojo. Plus they also have great hot chocolate, and coffee from local roaster La Terza. Don't miss out on one of the things that makes Cincinnati awesome.

The nutella is my favorite flavor.  I like to go by and pick up a couple of pints when we have people over if I don't feel like making dessert.  I have done that twice now and the owner has been great about letting me sample as many flavors as I want before making my choices.  He also fills the pints up to the very top which is great and well worth the money.

The Dojo has such unique flavors that I don't where to start. With flavors like Cap'n Crunch, Nutella, Cream Cheese, and many other unique choices, I had a tough time choosing. I took a free taste of some cherry flavor, and enjoyed it. After some debate though, I opted for a Nutella/Sea Salt and Caramel cup. You get two flavors in the small cup ($3.75) and up to four flavors in the large cup ($4.75), so no matter what, you get to try at least two new flavors. Dojo makes their gelato in small batches and they ensure quality ingredients. The gelato was amazing, and was at the same level as Graeter's. I am excited for the summer so that I will have an excuse to visit Findlay Market and enjoy some more gelato!

This is yummy stuff! I've been to the location at Findlay Market a number of times, and I even sought them out at the Crafty Supermarket this weekend. I'll admit, there are some flavors that I don't like, but they'll give you a sample if you ask nicely. In conclusion, I think you should try Dojo Gelato. As does everyone else who has reviewed this place!

Dojo means "training ground" in Japanese, but at Dojo Gelato in Findlay Market, they can take the training wheels off. The Vietnamese coffee gelato is not just inspired, it is sheer masterful genius. For more "traditional" flavors, the Dutch Chocolate and Bourbon Vanilla take basic to another level with purity of flavor. Add to that Dojo's commitment to hormone-free dairy products, no artificial flavors, and priority to sourcing ingredients locally, and you can have your taste carnival and feel good about it.

After trying some of the flavors Dojo Gelato had to offer at a Yelp event this past winter, I wanted to stop by while I was at Findlay Market to give it another try. I don't know what I'm missing....maybe I'm just spoiled by Jeni's ice cream in Columbus. Or maybe because I indulged in some Madison's Gelato right before coming here. Either way, I've tasted better gelato.

Do you know how Cincinnati people get all excited about food that really isn't very good? Dojo Gelato is a rare exception. If anything, it gets better every time I am there. I had the lemon cardamom today and it was wonderful - real flavors, complex flavors, not over-sweet like so much local food. The balsamic something-or-another (cherry?) was also lovely. The staff always gives great recommendations for combinations and that one small cup is more satisfying than a whole pot full of Graeters. It's worth every penny and it makes a real foodie smile.

I've definitely had better gelato.  I tried the mango sorbet one, and that was 'meh...just ok' at best.  The dutch chocolate was better, so it averaged out to a 2 star.  Better ice cream in town at graeters and yagoot...I'd pass on this one for sure.  Overpriced for 'meh' ice cream.  Only positive is that the selection is very interesting.

Going to Dojo Gelato is like an adventure. First, you need to push through the crowds in Findlay to get to their stand. Once you do, you are met with friendly faces and delicious treats. The flavors are constantly changing, with a few continuous favorites. Every flavor is so unique-- Mexican vanilla, coconut, eggnog, captain crunch and salted caramel (my absolute favorite!) I absolutely love Dojo, and the fact that they travel around and can be found at various events and street festivals is awesome. Only downside is that it's a little on the pricey side ($4 for a small and $5 for a regular). But, it is so delicious it's worth it.

I love Dojo! There are always new flavors and they're always tasty! My favorite was the spicy mango... it was like pow in my mouth! And... you can always taste a flavor using their reusable spoons! But no worries, they clean them of course! In fact, I'm going to get some right now!

absolutely awesome. have some strange flavors sometimes, but you can taste anything before you choose what you want. the Captain Crunch is to die for, along with the dutch chocolate! much better than any ice cream place in the city, just wish they had another location that was open later.

Some very interesting flavors offered here, making it a neat stop if you're wandering the market and want a little something to cool down with.  I'll admit a couple of the flavors didn't please everyone, but that's what you get when you try things like rosewater gelato...  by and large most of the offerings were tasty.

Can I add stars? Just multiply these stars because 5 is not good enough. Why do I love Dojo? Can we start with the flavors? Oh the flavors! I am actually partial to the fruit sorbettos myself, but never would I think I would want a frozen dessert with cilantro in it. But there it was and it was delicious!! I love the fact that I can sample any of the flavors before having to commit. I love that I can get multiple flavors per cup and that the bigger the cup the more flavors I get. I love that my brother, one of the pickiest eaters I know and one of the people who rarely shows any enthusiasm will not only go with me and try different flavors but actually seems to be enjoying himself. I love that going there feels like a special treat after a hard week. I love that they have a card where I can see just how much Dojo I have eaten and when I have eaten the right amount, I can get some for free. I love that they have a cart which goes to the Hyde Park Farmer's market which is right around the corner from me. This is one place you cannot miss.

i am just writing this review to try to harass michael into making coconut.  this is the only gelato flavor that i am aware of with its own fan club. michael never makes it because he claims it doesn't sell. anyone who is passing this up is going to have one more item on their list of regrets when they die.  COCONUT GELATO FOR LIFE!!!

One of the best meals I have ever had in my life. Went here for anniversary. Top Chef shows here. All of the meat (some of which I had never heard of) was absolutely ridiculously delicious. We started with the charcuterie board with the bacon, pork cheek (), two cheeses, relishes and jams. I am not a huge wine person usually, but the cab they paired was perfect.  Our server and all the others were very knowledgeable. Helped us pick the pork sugo and ny strip and a side to share.  Not a bad bite the whole meal. I hope to go back VERY soon!

Dear Butchery used to be Tellers. So walking into it we were expecting to see tellers, but instead we saw a beautiful new bar with a larger (bank) vault dining room, very nice interior, as well as the upstairs still. We were extremely pleasantly surprised.
They have a nice menu, but they were out of the fillet tonight and they were also out of oysters. So that's extremely disappointing. Instead we ordered a strip. Their strip is $110, kind of pricey. Is it worth $110?? Absolutely not. Was it good, yes. It was $50 good maybe. It's hard when you have a Jeff Ruby restaurant in Cincinnati because nobody does a steak better.  This makes Jeff Ruby steak pricing seem very reasonably priced, almost inexpensive even. 
The food was good. 
The charcuterie board was outstanding. 
We really enjoyed our waiter, Ben. 
However for the money, not sure we would go back.

We recently visited Dear Restaurant & Butchery for date night. At this price point, I would expect top notch service and food which did not happen. First let's start with the good. Cocktails were amazing and very creative, different then what you find elsewhere. Dessert was also really good.

But... when you charge these prices, everything should go off without a hitch. Service was mediocre at best. Overall it was slow and unresponsive. Specifically, after our waitress took our food order she said she's be back with some bread. That bread never came, and only after we finished our charcuterie and I asked about it did she remember to go get it.

Speaking of charcuterie, when it was dropped off at our table the runner did not have plates for us. He said he'd be "right back with share plates." It took about five minutes for him to come back with the two plates. Sit back and time out five minutes staring at your food unable to eat it only because you don't have a plate.

But if the food was amazing I could overlook the service hiccups, but it just wasn't. First the charcuterie. The meat was actually pretty good and unique, A for that. But the cheese was boring and basic. The Humboldt Fog they serve for $8/ounce is the exact same cheese you can get at Kroger for 25% of that price. It's a good cheese, but again at this price point I expect more.

Finally, and what really prompted me to take the time to write this review, was the steak. At $118 for a 12 ounce ribeye, I expect the best steak I've ever tasted in my entire life. The way the waitress explained how they make it and where it comes from it sounded like it would be. Don't get me wrong, it was a good steak. But Ruby's is better and half the price. My wife's filet was $98 for FOUR OUNCES and got the same review. This is all because it's Australian Wagu, but that's the only option. The chicken dish that seemed popular and was brought out at least 10 times after we ordered was already sold out by the time we placed our order.

So if our check for the night was $100 + tax/tip, I'd give this place 4 and a half stars. Great atmosphere, pretty good service, pretty good food. But when dinner for two costs $300 + tax/tip (for two drinks each, one split charcuterie board, one steak each, and one split dessert) in Cincinnati Ohio, you simply have to bring your A game. They either need to take a hard look at the quality of service and product at their price point, or adjust the price point. Until one of those two changes I won't go back.

Our friends dined here the week before and said don't go. The food and service was awful. We wanted to try anyway. They were correct. The menu looks impressive. It's actually deceiving- from start to finish! 
Let's start with 20+ minute wait for 2 glass wine pours and 2 cocktails. 
Charcuterie should be amazing as they center themselves around the idea. Boars Head meats have more flavor. The cheeses are just ok, and small! The side items were not impressive at all. 
App course: (ordered all 4) 1st two; tuna, then the hamachi crudo were over sauced/pickled. 3 very delicious and tiny oysters on the next app. The wagyu beef tartare was a large cut on a ground beef, meat grinder. This gave large fatty pellets of flavorless expensive beef- with kalamita olives, mint and parsley, an obscure cream sauce, topped with a very hard cracker. (This is the worst beef tartare I have ever had!) 
Long waits in between each course.
Server, Emily was nice.
Cocktail menu is creative and may be worth the wait, at times...
Wine somm should find a new career path. He doesn't describe wine with the correct knowledge. Absolutely stunning display of pretending. 
The side dishes were awful. If you describe pommes with the option to add caviar for $20, you may expect something nice. So we doubled the caviar serving to 12 grams. They serve turbinado sugar crusted, fried potato wedges (the only dish served kind of warm) topped with mediocre caviar! Are you serious?!
Every entree is described to have bacon in some way. (Please stop?) The pork chop was overcooked. The rabbit medallions (bacon wrapped) [pictured here] were tasty, yet the beautiful presentation had NO FLAVOR and was under-seasoned. The beef short rib was nice. For an entree that's said to serve 2-4 for $96, it should. 
Dessert.... 
Eclairs should resemble.... Ummmm, an eclair. They serve two rectangles of burnt chocolate cake with dots of cream in between. The panna cotta was a bit off as well, served with dry over baked Madeline cookies. 
Dinner for 4 was just shy of $700. 
We are really hopeful that they address these issues and succeed. 
It's been unfairly difficult for restaurants to make it through this past year. This is why we are frequently dining out now- to show them this is why they made it through the tough times. 
However, this experience is unacceptable. Please improve.

First review of the year! 
This resto got me curious with the reviews that I thought must try. Raging reviews of their short ribs and chicken is what I thought we should try. BUT WAIT... They offered a chef's hand special wc is a special 5 course carefully prepared & chosen by the chef at $80/person. As pricey as it seemed we thought it might be worth trying paired with a bottle of cab for $100. See the photos..
Started w/ an oyster (ok), small charcuterie (salami, fig, cheese), A shrimp escabeche (a little sour and pickled) followed by lamb sugo (it was tasty and tender) roasted broccolini and short ribs. They were tender and came with puffed pastry, I felt it can use more seasoning and sauce to it. It was good to say the least. 

Service was good but the wait of every plate was long. Overall experience though was disappointing. Everytime a resto offers a chef's selection special, that to me translates it to be something special and OFF the menu thus you pay a little extra. Only to be served basically everything on the menu shouldn't be called a Chef's Hand rather it was a SAMPLER. We could have ordered all of these ala cart for half the price. They made it up with a bottle of wine.

Total WOW factor! I loved Dear! I totally underestimated them. I heard great things but I just wasn't sure. I decided to try them one night and was so happy I did! Dear is a good date night or night out with the friends kind of spot. I went with my husband and two daughters. I made reservations through Open Table. When we arrived they checked us in and walked us to our seat. The decor and mood was perfect! The decor was bright yet cute. It made the vibe super cool yet, elegant with a chill. The service was also really good. 

Now time to talk about this killer food. The kitchen is ran by Executive Chef, Brian Young, and let me tell you, he is doing the damn thing!  He was a contestant on Food Network's Top Chef. That food was amazing! We tried dishes from all courses. We started with the Red Orche Salad and the Shrimp Escabeche. Both were very good and flavorful. The Shrimp came with some crunchy veggies to add a crunch element and a champagne reduction for some tang. The salad had this amazing "bird seed" crumble that was delicious. It added the perfect crunch. This dish was fresh and the dressing added a creamy component. 

For dinner we wanted to try quite a few things so we ordered the Short Ribs, Lamb Sugo and Chicken Fried Mushrooms. The ribs are braised for 72 hours. Yyyyaaalll, those ribs are slap your mama good! I mean fork only tender. They were so tender and flavorful. Literally, the second place ever in life I've had the best short ribs. Whew, I could go on and on. My 4-year-old even loved them. The Lamb Sugo is a gnocchi dish with a lamb ragu/pasta sauce. It sounds basic but it's so good! The Chicken Fried Mushrooms are a vegetarian dish. They were so flavorful and had the perfect crisp and crunch. It literally looked like fried chicken. It tastes really good. It came over a bed of risotto. Everything was amazing! 

We couldn't end a meal this good without dessert. We had their Sweet Potato Cake. It was moist and delicious. It was so perfect for the season and cold weather. It was warmed with the spices and hit the spot. We really enjoyed this dish.

Overall, I love Dear! The food is great! It's the perfect date night spot. However, it's also kid friendly. They have high chairs and cups with lids for children feeding. Also, check out their butchery. During the day you can get fresh cut sandwiches made at their walk-up window. It's super cute and cool! Check them out!

Talk about a place that will blow your mind!! When I first heard about Dear, I was excited but didn't know it would have such an impact on me. But it did! 

I went on a Friday night and thankfully had the ability to sit outside when the weather was still decent. Their patio is lovely! There's a full bar outside As well as a small amount of seats which help practice social distancing. The staff were all amazing. They were so attentive and knew the menu like the back of their hands. 

Speaking of menu, I cannot rave enough about how well done each dish was. The executive chef comes from Tennessee and was featured on bravo tab chef. I'm obsessed with that show! I'm so thankful that he came to Cincinnati and paired his creativity with the owners of the restaurant. This space has transformed into something so beautiful that I'm confident will go far. 
 
I still need to go back during the day and try their butcher, made to order sandwiches, coffee, and ice cream. 

It's an incredible place that I feel everyone will love!
Amazing! The restaurant is beautiful, our waiter was awesome and the food was fantastic! Thank you for such a beautiful evening!

Welcome to the neighborhood, Dear! This review is for the front coffeeshop / to-go / butcher shop portion of the restaurant. I look forward to updating this review once the dine-in section of the restaurant opens in August '20.

At first glance, Dear is charming from the street with flower boxes, powder blue door, and a subdued sans serif sign quietly announcing "we are open". The location is next to Graeter's in Hyde Park Square. 

Once you enter, it becomes clear the intention of Dear is anything thing but subdued. Premium butcher shop, wine offerings, coffee bar, to-go food, wine club, and icecream. Very ambitious.

We ordered the chorizo biscuit breakfast sandwich which was made with high quality ingredients. The latte and cold brew with house made sweet cream were both very good.

We chatted it up with the barista and learned they intend to open full scale dining in late Aug '20. He gave us a peak of the restaurant, which has an instagrammy vibe with millennial pink walls, palm-treeish wallpaper, and green velvet booth seating. 

Can't wait to return and try the full dining experience. If the quality of the front shop is any indication of the full shabang, this will be a vibey food destination in Cincinnati with aspirations of taking Hyde Park Square up a notch.

I had a reservation for my wedding anniversary dinner that I made a month in advance. I showed up today 6/6 at 645pm for Dear to be closed with no call to inform me that they cancelled my reservation. Now I have to scramble to save my anniversary dinner. Very unprofessional.

Not my character to complain about the opportunity to enjoy a dinner out but due to ALL the events that unfolded and lack of customer care this deserves to be shared. 
Mistakes can happen and are more than not very innocent and forgivable. 
I judge a restaurant on quality and customer care when. I can honestly say this restaurant failed on every level. 
One instance is spilling wine on 2 members of our party.....Offered to bring soda water without returning......Avoiding us at every cost. 
The biggest disappointment is the manager/owner was there and completely aware of every situation as it took place and never came to the table to address the situation which continued to go south. This restaurant has 5 star prices with 1 star delivery.

I've heard nice things about Dear and I had to set a reservation a couple of weeks in advance, so I was very excited to finally try this place out. It was a beautiful, sunny day so I was already in a very good mood. Upon being taken upstairs to our table, I squealed with delight at the gorgeous floral designs on the seats and the colorful paint on the walls that perfectly embodied Springtime! Add to that, our server Emily was very friendly, informative and professional. As for the food, it was a mix for me. The Lamb Gnocchi was TO DIE FOR and the charcuterie board was very good. The broccolini and my second drink were decent, but nothing spectacular. We were not impressed with our desserts though! My pound cake was dry and hard. I absolutely loved the Basic Instinct cocktail - it was tasty and came with a huge bubble on top for you to pop! Very cool. Overall, I approve of this place. They could stand to make a couple of small adjustments though.
Very clean and Covid safe. Extremely helpful and friendly staff. Amazing food and wine.

The most wonderful dining experience in Cincinnati to date! The service is spectacular, the drinks refreshing and the most amazing Chairman's Reserve Ribeye I have ever had in my life! Stop what you are doing and go to Dear as soon as possible!!!

Welcome to the neighborhood the pleasure is all ours! If you are dining in, ordering from the butcher case, grabbing a light meal on the go, or looking for a wine fix, Dear delivers an amazing experience across all fronts. 

During quarantine we've been going to Dear often to get their Spatchcock Chicken to smoke and it's both delicious and reasonable for a gourmet meal at home. 

Based on my previous experiences I was very much looking forward to dining in the beautifully renovated space and our dinner did not disappoint. Every dish was made with such thoughtfulness to flavor, texture, plating with an amazing sommelier who provided the perfect wine pairing recommendation. I had the yams, broccoli and lamb with gnocchi and it was all so delicious! I've already made my next reservation and recommend you make yours soon. 

As an added bonus Dear has a wine club and has been delivering wines to my door on a monthly basis and it's been both convenient and enjoyable to experience wines outside my norm. 

To the team at Dear, thank you for building such an incredible hospitality experience for your guests and our neighborhood.

This may be the most interesting menu in Cincinnati right now. It changes frequently, and is always fresh and flavorful. The wait staff are deeply knowledgeable about both menu and wine and the cocktails are superb. They've done a nice job with remodeling Tellers and every setting gives an unique experience.

What a great new addition to Cincinnati! We went here for dinner and enjoyed everything we ordered.  Started with oysters, prepared with cucumber, edible flowers and other delicious flavors followed by an excellent charcuterie board.  For entrees, my husband had the filet which was cooked to perfection and I had salmon which was also cooked perfectly.  Wine selection is excellent, service was exceptional, all around wonderful experience!

From the moment you see the blue door you know you're going to have a great time. Our server was amazing and took the time to answer our questions with the perfect amount of detail. The wine list speaks volumes about the thoughtfulness that goes into your experience.  The food is perfectly timed to where you never feel like your table is empty or your waiting, and everything is perfectly cooked and seasoned. I'd go there 5 nights a week for the tempura squash
Definitely will return!

It was such a pleasant experience. First a beautiful day for lunch and we enjoyed the grab and go style sandwiches to eat on the patio. Will definitely be back to try added items. Great new addition to the Hyde Park area!

The manager made sure they were able to accommodate my diet restrictions with the pre fix New Years menu. Codley our server was wonderful. He was efficient and read us very well. I went with my 3 year old and he made sure her and our needs were met so that she stayed on her best behavior until the end. Next year, once Covid is over my husband and I will definitely come back to enjoy a wonderful evening there. Thank you so much for making the last day of this difficult 2020 a wonderful night for me and my family

Outstanding evening!  The decor and remodel of the space is incredible and the food was simply fantastic!  The dishes were all a perfect taste of Fall with inventive flavors that far surpassed our expectations.  They were very accommodating of dairy allergy and went above and beyond on replacements.

I've eaten at some of the finest restaurants in Paris, and all over the world. Dear's culinary chef and staff offer an incredible menu that is out of this world amazing. The new space is also incredible. Very unique wine selection hand selected that is available in their store and on their menu. Reasonable in pricing as well. I rarely write reviews, but Dear is deserving of a 5 star review, hands down. Walk next door for Graeters ice cream after.

If you haven't been to Dear, you must go! If you HAVE been to Dear...go again. Everything was absolutely amazing from start to finish. The drinks are crafted to perfection, the food is delicious (an understatement), and the atmosphere is sophisticated yet unstuffy. All staff members were so kind and welcoming, and our bartender Nikki was especially fantastic! Without hesitation, if I could give everything way more than five stars, I would.

A perfect way to top off the weekend! Prosecco and dessert! I could sit in this restaurant for hours. The decor is tasteful to the last detail!
Will definitely be back. Thank you- job well done!

We had the most magnificent experience at Dear Restaurant!

The new interior space is unlike any other in Cincinnati. The attention to detail was extraordinary, the staff was spot on and the meal was scrumptious.

Run to Hyde Park Square to share the short ribs family style. These proprietors know how to make you feel "dear" to their heart. Can't wait to go back!

Well done!!

Move over Boca.  There are few things in life that I will spend a little extra money for but did is one of those items. 95% of the time this is debating on whether or not to splurge for the guacamole on my burrito. Also, my family has some great culinary skills, and we often find we can make things ourselves better than most restaurants. Thus, the restaurant has to make something really unique or perform at a high level to justify the expense.  One of our current favorites in Cincinnati is Boca, and we will often visit a couple of times a year for special occasions.  It is a rare gem where I know everything will be great. Yet, this incredible culinary experience has been bumped down to number two on our list after our dinner at Dear.  The interior is a wonderful mix of art deco with touches of modern elegance.  The service was attentive, knowledgeable and hospitable.  Every item was carefully explained and we had all of our needs anticipated.  There was also a great flow in the pace of the food. We never felt like we were really waiting for our food but did not rush the experience either.  However, the shining star was the food. We started with the charcuterie board with our personalized selections of meats and cheeses. All were amazing, and we only regretted there was not more because we enjoyed every bite.  The main courses were NY strip, Pork Sugo, and the Short Ribs. All of them were prepared, seasoned and cooked to perfection.  However, the Short Rib was the shining star. It is enough for two hungry people or three normal appetites.  Thus, it is meant to share.  It takes three days to cook and prepare but the end product is worth the investment. It is comfort food at its best on steroids.  The scene from the movie Ratatouille came to mind, and I swear I heard some jazz playing as we savored each amazing bite.  The dinner concluded with a well balanced chocolate tart and Ethiopian coffee.  It was perfection from start to finish. If my bank account would allow me, I would eat here once a week.  However, I must reserve this for my next moment of indulgence. We will be back, but we hope it will be very soon.  That scoop of guacamole on my burrito can only carry me so far for so long.

We had the opportunity to attend one of their soft opening patio dinners and it was wonderful. The wine selection was the absolute best. There was a struggle to get a table, but the service, meal, and wine pairing were divine, that we will be back and be joining the wine club.      Austin the wine director was a delight.

We've been carrying out from the butchery since Dear opened and finally dined-in. Not surprisingly, the food was delicious! Great service too, felt very safe and comfortable despite the pandemic. Gnocchi was my favorite, with ALL of the vegetables. Hope you enjoy as much as we did!

This place is BEAUTIFUL! I cannot imagine having designed a better space and the peak into the main dining area is very exciting. I stopped in for the to go counter that is currently open. Clearly a lot of thought went into every detail here from the labels to the design of the fridges and the tile and menu. It's all amazing! Such a welcome addition to the neighborhood. My only complaint would be the price for what you get. A grab and go sandwich for $12 plus a small side of a fairly bland green bean salad that was $10. So $22 for a very light lunch. They had a side of mushrooms for $15 that looked to be about one serving. The ingredients clearly were quality but there are places offering high quality grab and go lunch for much much less. I have high hopes for the main restaurant space, will definitely be back and LOVE what they are doing but price wise for a quick lunch this is steep even for someone willing to pay for quality food.

Great service and delicious icecream! The 2 guys working were super friendly and nice to chat with. The icecream was so smooth, creamy and thick. I liked that there were so many menu options and you could really customize anything!

This ice cream spot was in the Over The Rhine area in Cincinnati and was pretty cool! We went right before they closed and the workers were super nice about it which was cool. You basically can pick whatever flavors you want in your ice cream and choose to have it "buzzed" with adding alcohol or not. They also have recommendations on the menu for which ones to put with which flavors which is super helpful if it's your first time there. I didn't get a buzz ice cream this time but will for sure be back to try that out! The ice cream was the liquid nitrogen kind that they make right in front of you so I ordered Espresso and peanut butter! The ice cream was insanely soft and it was just really good. Got to try a bite of mint chocolate chip as well and that will probably be what I go with next time- super cool spot!

Could have been a lot better! MY friend and I have not been able to make to this Cincy "hotspot" . It was late almost closing time, we planned to get it to go. I used to be a server so get it wanting to get home after a shift.  The cashier was super nasty. If not for the mask he would have litterly would have spit " We close in 15 mins and it's take out only!" OK then buddy cool your jets. We both chose the apple pie.... who ever made this recipe has NEVER had apple pie. It was vanilla ice cream over graham crackers. 
Maybe he realized how rude he sounded because he tempered his tone with the couple behind us or maybe it was our Blackness and their whiteness that tempered his tone. I see it so much I'm giving him the benefit of the doubt, because this is more about service and product. 
I'm giving these stars to the quiet man working behind the counter who "Said have a good night."

To be quite honest, I was not expecting this place to be as good as it was! I thought it was just going to be a trendy little experiment that fizzled out quickly as people got bored of it because it wasn't REALLY that great.

I was WRONG.

This place was SO delicious. The alcohol pairs perfectly with the ice cream, and was not too sharp and didn't burn at all like I thought it would as it is uncooked. I got the Honey Bourbon Pecan, but shared the Death By Chocolate and Buzzed Bull with friends. We all agreed that they were all delicious, but the Honey Bourbon Pecan was the best of the three. The regular size was almost too much, and I left feeling very full, but satisfied! My only negative was the ice cream left my tongue feeling a little freezer burnt... I wonder if that's one of the results of using liquid nitrogen. It's not enough to deter me though--  I will definitely be back!

I love ice cream in all forms, scoops, shakes, sandwiches, sundaes. It's all good. That being said I was super excited about trying Buzzed Bull. I mean ice cream made with liquid nitrogen and a little booze, amazing right? 

You walk in and are greeted by a very clean and loud atmosphere. Tables and seating on the left and the line where all the magic happens on the right. To order you walk to the back of the restaurant pick your poison and watch them make it. There's a wide selection of suggested options as well as a create your own choice for the creatives. You can have alcohol or not so it's definitely still a family friendly experience. The staff was really nice about explaining and making their own suggestions about what pairs well together. 

Ultimately I opted for the apple pie shake with apple pie moonshine. The presentation was a little weak, there was a little whipped cream crushed by hunks if graham cracker, so not super pretty. The shake itself was a little runnier than I prefer but the flavor was there, you could definitely tell that it was apple pie. The alcohol content was pretty low, so don't expect to get "buzzed" from this. The shake was good, I really wanted to love it but it wasn't an "out of this world" experience. I wouldn't need to make a special trip just to go back. I think Buzzed Bull is more of a once in a while novelty treat, it's not something you crave or just necessarily need in your life.

We stopped in one afternoon and it wasn't too crowded, but still is a process to get your order entered and made. It was fun to see them working with the liquid nitrogen and seeing how complex the process really is.
We split the tiger stripes shake and it was so much we were stuffed. Unfortunately we took it to go so missed out on the buzzed part.
If you have your dog with you note there is no outdoor area to enjoy the alcohol part of your dessert.
We may try it again when downtown, but I won't go out of my way. Would personally prefer Graeters or Aglamesis.

I can't say enough about this place. The young man who served me was so cool and knowledgeable. A real believer in ice cream and spirits ;) my kinda guy! I enjoyed a great honey vanilla with graham crackers whipped cream and honey drizzle ...with bourbon!!!! Soo good. My date had a combo that touted chocolate vodka. It was good too! Servings are worth it! Milkshakes available as well. I'm loving the revitalization in this part of Cincy! Makes our town so fun! Get to the Bull!

I have visited twice in the last two weeks. Each time I have visited the ice cream has been grainy. It is not smooth like ice cream should be and has been before from Buzzed Bull. My bf & I have been customers for over a year now. However, it has been disappointment for the last few visits :(

It was simply ok. 

This was all about the experience and trying a new ice cream parlor with an adult beverage flare. 

Visited on a Saturday evening around 11 pm during a heat wave. Was able to enjoy the A/C while ordering and watching the creations being infused with Nitrogen to make a firm ice cream concoction. 

Ordered the Lemon Cake, with the suggested bourbon. It did have a lemon taste but wasn't creamy ice cream. I would revisit only in taking someone from out of town that was interned, but would try something different. 

Plenty of seating to enjoy your adult ice cream and laughs. 

Note, Since it contains alcohol you must consume onsite.

Omg, have you ever had ice cream with booze in it?  If, not you need to get to this place.  so many flavors of ice cream to choose from, add inns and a plethora of boozes to include in your concoction.

Great concept!  Love the fun options - both buzzed (alcoholic) and not buzzed (non-alcoholic).  We tried the nitro shake in strawberry and the ice cream buzzed Bonfire.  Was much happier with the ice cream version- the shake was too runny for me.  Overall, was a fun place to visit on a Friday night.  Would be a neat place to have an after dinner visit for a date. We were with 3 teens - all who seemed to enjoy (meaning, family friendly spot too).

I've been staying at one of the "best" hotels in Cincinnati this weekend that can't even manage to serve ice cream in their 2 restaurants.  Enter the Buzzed Bull Creamery and Doordash.   We got Tiger Stripes and the Red Leg and just know, they are completely orgasmic sensations.  Ice cream fixes everything.  Just try anything that tickles your fancy on the menu, I'm sure it's bound to be as good as our sampled flavors.

I mostly love Buzzed Bull Creamery. The experience is fun and the end result is super tasty! It's clean, modern and wonderfully run as a family business. They cater to any ages with their Buzzed and non-Buzzed options of ice cream, milkshakes and hot drinks with their yummy cream base!

Everything starts as a base and goes from there. I chose a predesigned concoction; a small Buzzed Creamsicle ice cream. Hubs designed his own, vanilla ice cream with snickers and butterfinger, non-buzzed. Pro tip, download the app for 2 free mix ins. 

The possibilities are endless here. So many options! Plenty of tables and chairs and a few high chairs(!!) so you have plenty of space to enjoy your treat. Alcoholic ice cream can't leave the premises. 

Something for me and others to consider next time; I didn't even come close to finishing half of my buzzed ice cream. Essentially, I paid over $7 and wasted a shot of vodka. I think next time I'll stick with non-buzzed and just enjoy the experience.

A delightful and unique offering in OTR. The ice cream itself is very tasty and the addition of shots is a fun experience. I'm just not sure that the total is greater than the sum of the parts. Ice cream is great. Alcohol is great. Alcoholic ice cream is good. The nitrogen (like Dippin Dots) also starts to give your tongue an odd little aftertaste. This should absolutely be an experience on your "Things to Do in OTR list," but it is more a once in a while than all the time event. 
Bonus: they have a flight option for 11 dollars and it gives you 4 different 4 oz samples.

Cool concept -- ice cream that's buzzed with  booze and nitrogen. Tried it with friends after a big meal and walk at Kaze, so arrived quite late at night. It was still open and lots of people around. The line was not very long but it took forever to move. The couple that ordered before us took almost 20 mins to download and app and complete their order--very annoying. 

We shared their butter pecan ice-cream that was buzzed with cognac and with a brownie topping. Honestly, the ice cream itself was average and the combo tasted okay. Our friends got some of the advertised specials rather than trying by themselves and they were also similarly okay. One of them tasted like rum and raisin. Not great, not bad. 

I would give it 3 stars based on the ice-cream but 5 stars on the concept. Perhaps, we didn't order the right flavors for us, so it's worth checking out on your own -- I plan to give it another try.

You'd think when you go some place the menu item that is named after the name of the restaurant (or vice versa) would be the best item on the menu - well this is not true at Buzzed Bull.

I have only been here once and that is because my one experience was not great - I ordered "The Buzzed Bull" which is coffee flavored ice cream, bourbon, caramel, nuts and whipped cream - it sounds delicious and since it has the same name as the place I figured it HAD to be the best ice cream on the menu - but boy was I wrong.

I was very let down with the flavor and flavor pairing that went into this ice cream, I tasted some of my friends' who were there, one had The Tiger Stripe, and two friends mixed their own - all of which tasted light years better than The Buzzed Bull I ordered.

Outside the taste, I knew I was going to be paying a premium for this ice cream due to the fact they use liquid nitrogen to make it, but really to me $5+ for a small is a little insane! - especially when the flavor is not good!
I understand it is a niche and super trendy - but if the ice cream isn't even good then what are you paying for?!

Overall, I think Buzzed Bull is definitely a very expensive / premium treat. Maybe next time I have family / friends in town visiting I would take them here, and would definitely be mixing my own flavors - but the sheer expensiveness and lack of flavor / deliciousness who knows if I will ever be back!

Rankings on the Morgan scale:
Experience: 7/10
Drink Price: N/A
Food Price: 3/10

Pretty fun ice cream concept. Choose your ingredients, they mix them together and the do a flash freeze  with nitrogen. Very fun to watch. Like a good science project! The concoction is then scooped into a bowl or a shake.  Was both fun to choose, fun to watch and delicious to eat!  and COLD!  You can even add in your favorite adult beverage if you're legal.  Just in time for the warm weather!
Alcohol and ice cream, yes please. It's nitrogen ice cream, so be aware as the flavor is distinct.  The staff are really friendly and the vibe is nice. Highly recommend!

Ice cream & alcohol. Need I say more? 

Delicious cream is sprinkled with various toppings & a shot of liquor is added to the cream. The cream is then placed into a Kitchen-Aid mixer , faceted w/ an arm for a liquid nitrogen pour! The liquid nitrogen is cold enough to freeze not only the cream, but the liquor as well! 

The flavor of the alcohol is very present so this may not be for everyone if you don't enjoy the actual taste of alcohol. 

On that note, you can also get Ice cream without liquor for those under 21 or for those who just don't enjoy alcohol. 

A very unique experience , but a delicious one! Be prepared to wait if you come during a busy time!

Not bad....but there is better ice cream in the world. 

Came here with a group of friends on an early Saturday evening this summer. It was pretty quiet when we cam in but traffic picked up very quickly after.

For some reason, it took a long time to actually order our ice cream. The menu is a little large and there are a lot of options and toppings and mix-ins for people who struggle with decisions. I really liked how you can watch the ice cream being made. That being said it's craziness behind the counter and when a line forms, the place gets even crazier.

Even after ordering, it took about 10 minutes for me to get my order. I believe we had a vanilla ice cream with bourbon and maybe cookie dough? Wasn't very memorable and it was a lot to eat even shared between myself and another person.

I guess I went for the experience because I haven't been back since.

Ice cream for adults!! YES! I never thought I needed boozed mixed ice cream until I tried it. The Buzzed Bull with bourbon is where it's at y'all. I came here with a group of friends and tried all of theirs so I'm pretty confident that mine had the most booze flavor. The smokey bourbon went so well with the coffee and caramel flavors. It was heavenly. Portions are very generous. I shared my "small" cup with a friend and was pretty full. Most of my friends couldn't finish theirs. 
Not sure if you want to finish your night off with a dessert or a drink. Why not both! Perfect way to end a night after dinner.

This was our last stop of our anniversary weekend and what a great way to end it! I got the Buzzed Red Leg milkshake and she got the Buzzed Dreamsicle milkshake. Both were very flavorful! We've had alcoholic or cream before but it tasted like alcohol, this place has the right recipe! We will definitely be back on our next trip to Cincy!
Great ice cream, with the bonus of having alcohol. I would recommend the tiger stripes, or the hard apple pie. Both are delicious!

Yoooooo! I wish I could give this place a 10!!!! Price point is right where it needs to be for this amazing tasting fresh ice cream. Never had anything like it and my taste buds are itching for it every time I want ice cream. Will be returning every single time I return to Cincinnati. Loved it so much I went two days in a row!

Staff is friendly, establishment is clean, and it is so cool how you can mix in the different flavors and sit by while they make your custom ice cream from scratch! Loved every second of it.

this is indeed a great idea, I was really excited to finally  give it a try and sadly I'm disappointed.  After all the reviews I still wanted to find out for myself and as much as I wanted to like it just because the concept it's so amazing I couldn't. 

The actual place is cool, neat, welcome ish, and the service it's also good.  Not the best service ever but not the worse either.  I really think that they should give you some sort of ideas of what flavors would work other than their signature ice creams or what not. 

Lastly and most important, the ice cream.. well, not the worse bit defined nowhere near being good.  Flavorless, watery and all you can taste she is water down alcohol.  Even worse the price for it is sky rocket for no reason, I would not pay that much for the taste they offer.

I suggest you to give it a try jut because of the ideas, I me who knows maybe some other flavor is better.

Never been to this establishment before my husband and i decided to stop in and experience the infused ice cream, we both ordered something different from each other so that we could taste test each other's, mine being a banana split with Cherry Vodka and he had chosen the Bonfire which includes chocolate chips, graham crackers and Fireball whiskey. Needless to say we were impressed with the flavor, very tasty using good amounts of ingredients in our serving. I can say their staff was very friendly and knowledgeable with all their menu items and recommendations, was very clean we really enjoyed our visit. Will definitely be back!
I really enjoyed this place! I got a Dreamsicle Buzzed Nitro Shake and the husband got a Red Leg Nitro Milkshake. Both were delicious! We'll be back on future trips to Cincinnati!
It's ice cream, alcohol, and a show! Are you not entertained! The staff was great and very friendly. I recommend the red leg. I would give it a 3.5 on the scale. Basic ice cream with a great kick!

This place is great! I got to meet a friend there my first night back in town and it was the perfect treat. I created my own. I went all with a large - cake batter ice cream with hot fudge, Reese's and Oreos. The large is definitely large! And with the small bites I take it last me for a nice thirty minute walk around OTR. The nitrogen process makes the ice cream quite firm to start. But then it's melts into perfectly creamy goodness!

My buddy apparently comes all the time. Each visit, he crafts a new concoction. I tried a bite of his - some kind of coconut craziness - and it was great!

I went here with my friend yesterday night and was so hapky they are open late. My friend got a buzzed cherry flavored ice cream -the cherry codial- and it tasted AMAZING. I got a simple non buzzed pineapple milkshake that was really good to. We even got some homework done here. Really nice ambience and desserts. Staff kept checking in to see if we liked our desserts too, which was sweet.

Buzzed Bull, what happened to you???
I am writing this update in a hope that the management reads the feedback and will address it!

My first 2 experiences were great, had a Margarita ice cream and one of the pre-thought mixes  from the menu (with bourbon), the ice cream tasted great and I was a great fan of the place.

But on a recent visit I had a long awaited ice-cream flight, sounded so cool. 
The flight consisted of 4 small plastic cups on a wooden tray that was premade, taken straight from the deep freeze and handed to me. 
First of all, in my mind, this place should be about seeing how the ice cream is made! The liquid nitrogen and all the hocus-pocus feeling is definitely included in the high price mark and I was slightly disappointed that the flight was pre-made. On the other hand, there was no wait time, which is a small pro. 
Second and most important: the flight was just bad. Each ice cream tasted the same, like a frozen half-and-half cream. It was not sweet enough, blant, I dunno, just so disappointing. Instead of a rewarding treat, I got a meh dessert that will make me think twice before heading there again.

Please, bring your A-game on! Do not cut the corners :/

DELICIOUS! 

How many times did you have to show ID to get an ice cream? First one for me, definitely not the last one.

Read the instructions on the board, pretty straight forward. Either made to order, totally customizable, or pre-defined 'specialty' orders.

Each alcohol can be upgraded to a shelf higher from the 'house' option.
Endless possibilities.

Quite a crowd showed up today, but the orders were coming consistently at a fast pace. Lots of seating inside.

My Buzzed Bull specialty was AWESOME. Coffee ice cream with house bourbon, nuts and caramel. The mysterious smoke of liquid nitrogen and the excitement: free! 

Good treat, not cheap (7.60 for small specialty), but if you see how laborious it is, you'll appreciate. 

Cheers!

Great concept, and excellent location in the heart of OTR. You truly get a unique experience when you walk in -- a plethora of both alcoholic and non-alcoholic options, watching the nitrogen vapor spill out as your ice cream is made right in front of you. On top of that, the staff is incredibly friendly and help you a lot in picking out what you want...there are A TON of different combinations. 

In all honesty, I was expecting more out of the ice cream. It wasn't bad, (how could ice cream ever be bad?!) but it wasn't anything too special considering the price. I'm giving a 4/5 stars, because although I love concept and the experience, the ice cream wasn't anything "a-ha!" worthy.

Excellent ice cream.  Since I'm not that into the taste of alcohol I'll get my next one un-buzzed. Overall, the taste and the creamy factor was excellent! The use of nitrogen to make the liquid ingredients freeze into ice cream is done right in front off your face... behind the glass shield,  like a science experiment.  You can order any concoction your mind can think of into your ice cream. If you want a long island iced tea, do it! Six shots & $30 later you will be a happy customer.  There's three sizes, you choose.  There's buzzed and un-buzzed, alcohol or non alcoholic. Ice cream can be $6 or as high as you make it. You can use regular liquor, mid.or top shelf liquor. You can use mix ins or toppers. The sky is the limit. 
A tip: going on a rainy night could be your best bet to avoid the lines.

Saw an article on this, and HAD to visit this new favorite in my hometown of Cincinnati! The atmosphere is a kid between an ice cream parlor with a new, hip twist! Plenty of seating, and casual enough for a family with children. 

You have a choice between fun flavored ice cream and frozen yogurt, with a variety of toppings.  The real fun comes with choosing your "buzz"- Various house, mid-level, and top shelf liquors. Note that there's is a price difference in the tier of alcohol choices. My mix was the honey bourbon ice cream with bourbon, chunks of snickers, topped with fresh (non-alcoholic...womp) whipped cream. It was absolutely delicious.

These sweet treats are a bit pricey, but with a full shot of liquor in each buzzed bowl, I consider it to be comparable to a drink at the bar.  Great place to check out on a sunny day!

Love this concept! When alcohol and ice cream are two of your favorite things to consume, what could be better?

Came here on a Friday night and the place was PACKED, which we expected since it's brand new. The place is decently spacious, with a good amount of seating inside. 

We waited in line for about 30 minutes or so, but it was worth it for sure. They make their ice cream from liquid nitrogen, so it's fun to watch the whole process while waiting. I ordered the most popular creation, the Bonfire, which is vanilla ice cream + fireball + chocolate chips + graham cracker crumbs. It worked very well - the fireball was evident but not overpowering. You can also order ice cream non-"buzzed" if you're not in the mood for booze!

Will certainly be back! You can always count on OTR when it comes to having hot new businesses with unique concepts like this one!

I think buzzed bull has a great concept and the ice cream is delicious. 

You can definitely taste the alcohol which I think is good. But if you're not in the mood for the taste of a stiff drink, do non alcoholic! It's still fun to get to pick your mix ins. 
The staff can also help you pick a liquor that will compliment your creation. And I'm sure they will tell you which liquors stand out the most in your ice cream. From my experience bourbon can be a bit overpowering but vanilla vodka blends in more. 

I did a non alcoholic vanilla with cookie dough and brownies and peanut butter on top. It was excellent! And the small is generous. I definitely was satisfied. 
I will point out that there aren't going to be chunks of anything because they blend it together but I did taste the flavors of my mix ins. 

It's also sure to impress your out of town guests!

Finally tried this place on a hot day after hearing about it for so long ! Cool concept, you can get the ice cream "buzzed" or not buzzed (but y are you here if you're doing that???). I got the Red Leg which was delicious but didn't really taste boozy at all. My friend had the apple pie with cinnamon whisky I think - so good!!! I would NOT recommend the s'mores one though. Looks so good on the menu... but we all agreed that that one just tasted off. It's a fun place to go on a hot day, would be a good stop during day drinking in the summer!

Heard about this place awhile back and was excited when they finally set any opening date. I had to come try it and was worth it.  Because my friend and i had been here it was a little hard to understand how everything worked abd What to order.  The line was pretty long so at the same time we didn't want to hold anyone up.   The lady at the counter suggested to do the "flight" which was a sample of 4 different flavors.  So web went ahead and decided to get that.  Which didn't take long to get since they were pre made already.

The "flight"included the 4 flavors of the month in which the lady said that every month the flavors change. Out of the flavors of the month my favorite to sample was the birthday cake,  it had just enough alcohol mixed in with the ice cream.  Very delicious.  My least favorite was the peanut butter only because I don't like peanut butter in a form of ice cream. The other least favorite was the strawberry flavor one which had a lot of alcohol in it.  It was very overpowering and I couldn't really taste the ice cream.    After i mixed it up a little it was better.   I think the alcohol had settled at the bottom.  

Overall the ice cream with alcohol is a great concept.   I will definitely come back.  There is other flavors I would love to try specifically the death by chocolate one!

What is ice cream? Sure, it's ice and cream, but mostly it's process. In a city with a rich history in ice cream making (Graeter's), there's a high standard. Buzzed Bull tries something unique not just in flavor but in process. Unfortunately, they've got neither of these things right. 

First of all, before even discussing what's going on here on a taste experience standpoint, we've got this liquid nitrogen aspect that totally blows. It flash freezes the cream they use to mix with alcohol. What it doesn't do is develop any of the great aspects of ice cream. They've presumably left out the homogenization of ingredients, as well as the aging time for ice cream to get good. Also there's no creamy sensation to speak of. And worst of all it leaves a horrible tongue feel, similar to burning your tongue on pizza. Then it leaves a unpleasant aftertaste. Even the FDA recommends against any point of sale Liquid Nitrogen use. 

Okay. So we've most past the liquid nitrogen, and we don't care about ice cream process, then how is the end product? Lackluster at best. No real flavor to speak of. Total lack of tongue coating pleasure you would want from cream or alcohol. And how could one possibly justify taking a bourbon like Elmer's T Lee and blasting it into frozen oblivion? 

If you're an out of towner, please skip this and walk down the street to one out nations greatest creameries.

Yes. Yes yes yes. It's alcohol and it's ice cream. The staff was friendly, the space was nice, and the options were plentiful. Also, it was fun to watch the ice cream be made. There are plenty of top shelf options for upgrading your alcohol selection, and a variety of interesting pre-established things you can order. We went in at an off time and got our options right away.

My only complaint is the cost- and for additions. The base options are good, but it makes customizing seem a little more tedious and expensive than necessary, which puts a cap on being truly adventurous.

Trendy, cool ice cream shop concept. I didn't realize that the ice cream would be made with liquid nitrogen, but it makes sense. It allows the menu to be totally customizable. The draw is that you can get your treat "buzzed"--they even have top shelf options! You have almost too many choices! Luckily for people like me, they have suggested creations on the menu. I got a strawberry margarita sorbet. I didn't really taste the tequila at first because the sorbet is so sweet, but it was definitely there. And I was surprised at how big my small serving was! It equated to about a scoop or a scoop and a half. I figured that would be the size of a "regular". A small will run you $5-$8, so it was a pleasant surprise to get that much, which includes about a shot of liquor, for that price. 

The shop is family and kid friendly, despite what you might assume based on the concept. All ages are welcome to indulge "non-buzzed". When I visited on an overcast, but hot, Saturday afternoon they stayed pretty consistently busy. They are open late, which is really neat. Totally great for a late night treat or alternative to a bar.

The concept of this ice cream parlor is so cool, literally.

The first thing I noticed upon entering were the clouds coming off the liquid nitrogen, which is used to flash freeze your alcoholic dessert.  WHOA.

I excitedly tried to get in line, but the set-up of their shop is a little tricky for this; they take your order all the way near the back of the room, so you have to squeeze by everyone who is waiting to pick-up their dessert to get in line.  As I waited in line, I tried to decide what to order, but the way their menu was laid out was pretty confusing and I got very overwhelmed.

I don't eat ice cream very often because it often upsets my stomach, so even the small seemed a bit large for just me.  My husband decided he wanted to try the peanut butter ice cream with chocolate chips in it, but no alcohol.  My head was still spinning from the menu, so I just decided to split it with him.  We went with two other friends, who were splitting the Honey Bourbon Ice Cream.

It was about 4pm on a Saturday and they were pretty busy, but they had plenty of tables available and a number system for calling out orders, so it didn't feel too chaotic.

I really was very happy with our order.  Though it was just chocolate and peanut butter, I felt like the ice cream was very rich and creamy and absolutely overtook UDF as my favorite Ohio ice cream brand.  I also got to taste my friends honey bourbon ice cream and I thought it was delicious.  It was definitely strong on the alcohol, but if I'm going to pay that much for "buzzed" ice cream, I better taste the booze!  I did feel like the honey bourbon ice cream was almost painfully cold to the taste.  I have to imagine this has something to do with the liquid nitrogen, because my non-alcoholic ice cream was no colder than I would expect.

I really liked this place.  Their service was nothing memorable, the setup of the shop is not great, and the menu is confusing, but I think once they work out some of the kinks of being new to business, this place will be one of my absolute favorites!

Never thought my wife would have to drive me home after eating ice cream?
But she did.
This place is so different and so good.
They literally make the ice cream in a mixer while you wait. literally yes.
And is it so good. You can get non buzzed maybe a good thing if you are alone ha ha.
Big big big selection. Prices bit high and a tad of a walk from center of otr.
But what a great concept.
And so my wife could not finish her medium bowl and we took it home. We live about 25 minutes away and WOW it wasn't even melted when we got home. Crazy. 
Go here and cheers.

This is a review of Buzzed Bull as a dessert caterer, rather than an ice cream shop.

When we were planning March 2019 wedding, one of the first things we thought of was that we wanted to have ice cream instead of cake, and we wanted to make up our own flavors.  This seemed like a pipe dream until we found Buzzed Bull.  Kaitlyn was great!  She met with us multiple times to talk about flavors and logistics, and based on our conversations, she and her team created custom flavors that we absolutely loved.

On the day of the wedding, everything was where it needed to be.  The ice cream was delivered packed in large coolers with dry ice so it stayed plenty cold until being served; in fact, the leftovers made it until the next day when we were able to put them in our freezer at home.

The price was great, for a service that, as far as I can tell, nobody else provides.  We highly recommend you think outside the cake box and consider having Buzzed Bull ice cream for your wedding!

So there's a place that's serving liquid nitrogen flash frozen liquor infused ice cream in OTR. That's basically the Fast and The Furious of ice cream so I had to try. 

Shockingly the place was dead on a Saturday night when I arrived, but within minutes it got packed. Because every order is made fresh it takes a little bit of time to get yours so plan accordingly. 

Lots of choices so either check the menu ahead of time or know you make take awhile to order. You can choose a preselected combo or freestyle and go non-buzzed (alcohol free) or buzzed (up to 3 shots in your order!). Tons of mix-ins to try, but I did think it was a miss there was no fresh fruit.

I tried the White Russian (vodka and kahlua) and subbed the coffee ice cream for vanilla froyo and added in cookie dough. Great combo and it definitely had a kick. I do think the alcohol taste is dependent upon what you get because my husband got the Tiger Stripes (rum based) and it didn't really pack a punch.

Tip: If you get something containing alcohol, it must be consumed onsite.

I can't wait to go back and play around with the choices!

The best way to take shots on a Friday afternoon ;)

Buzzed Bull Creamery adds 1, 1.5, or 2 shots to your ice cream, depending on what size you order. I have tried the Buzzed Bull and the Death by Chocolate. Both are yummy. You can also make your own mix. If you decide to add alcohol to your mix, you do have to show your ID and cannot consume your ice cream outside the shop. 

They also offer a flight of 4 flavors. Sounds like a great way to try out many flavors, but I decided not to go this route since they prepackage these and just take it out of the freezer. I opted for two small cups instead to see how everything was mixed.

Buzzed bull infuses your ice cream and alcohol with nitrogen. It's fun to watch. I can definitely taste the alcohol content. This is a fun place to hang out and try out something new.

Great date spot for after dinner. Can't beat Graeter's but nice to change it up. You can get spiked and non-spiked. I like the Mint Brownie, so good and rich. Fiancé likes the tiger stripes... 
sometimes can take a long time if the line is long. They need to probably get a few more mixers going on busy nights. Cool spot. Definitely something to try out!

My wife and I visited Buzzed Bull Creamery yesterday after dining at LouVino, which is just down the street.  I am an ice cream junkie, eating enough over the last 30+ years that I shouldn't be alive to pen this review - the longstanding joke in my family is that I do not have a sweet tooth, but rather an "ice cream tooth".  With the previous being stated, it is tough to impress me when it comes to ice cream.

This was our first time at this establishment, but it had been on my radar for several months due to the intriguing alcohol/ice cream combo.  The menu board was a little confusing, but lucky for us the creator of the concept was working and explained things a little further.  Basically, if you are a newbie, just stick to the first menu panel on the left.  Here you can find popular flavor combos the staff/owners have already come up with.  I opt for the Lemon Cake with Gin - the price?  A shockingly high $8 for a small - a price I am gladfully willing to pay providing this blows my socks off into northern Kentucky, unfortunately, this wasn't the case.  Buzzed Bull Creamery has a lot going for it: friendly and helpful staff, unique concept, great location, nice interior space, etc.  What it didn't have going for it with this particular menu offering was "good ice cream".  I ordered exactly as listed on the menu with no additions/subtractions expecting a fantastic dish and honestly it was just bad.  Nothing about this worked.  No sweetness, a hint of a strange lemonish chemical flavor, no creaminess, a harsh alcohol flavor - whip cream was good, but this wasn't homemade.  Three stars for all the positives previously listed, but taste is king and this just didn't do it for me, or my better half.  My wife highjacked my ice cream before I could take a bite and quickly stated, "you aren't going to like that".  I should mention that you don't HAVE to have alcohol spiked ice cream - you can choose a regular ice cream dish sans alcohol, which may be a more tasty option.  

I will definitely be back to try another menu item and will adjust my review accordingly.
